to be an expert on the disease of addiction but I do have lived experience I've been in recovery from alcohol
addiction for over 17 years I spent 15 of those years in silence keeping my
recovery in the closet like a shameful secret sadly only 1 in 10 people who
need treatment for addiction actually seek treatment I know I know that
because I was one of those people I knew
for years that I had an addiction but I didn't seek treatment because I was
ashamed for people with the disease of addiction three words have deprived them
of medical treatment empathy and compassion for decades or more like
centuries and those three words are shame stigma and discrimination my
journey with addiction started when I was in high school in North Dakota when I first started drinking I knew he's a
teenager that I didn't drink like others I experienced my first blackout when I
was in high school I struggled with alcohol related issues and episodes over the next 20 years of my life I chose to
live and work in cultures with excessive drinking I had no desire to attend events that didn't include alcohol like
you wouldn't catch me at one of these events and I couldn't imagine my life without alcohol while constantly
struggling with my addiction my career progressed and I had forward movement in my life but I could never reach my full
potential with my addiction holding me back there came a time when I knew I
needed to stop drinking but addiction is a powerful disease and it kept me
drinking for many years I could achieve any goal I set for myself but I could
not stop drinking even though I experienced many defeating demoralizing
and baffling drunk episodes I'd stopped drinking for three months and then I'd
start again I'd stop for a year and then I'd start drinking again and this cycle
continued over a period of eight long years I am so grateful that my higher
power kept asking me to pull on my boots and try again and I finally became willing to do
whatever it would take to stay sober and when I became completely willing that's when the miracle happened for me and I
started staying sober I found a program that's built on a foundation of
gratitude helping others and a higher power and it saved my life
and I will forever be grateful to this
program and its people for embracing me and helping me find recovery this
unexpected journey has opened doors that are helping me to reduce the barriers
shame and stigma that I faced during my own recovery journey my platform is
called recovery reinvented and it's now known throughout the state of North
Dakota and it's truly a team effort that includes the governor our behavioral
health team and my own team of rock stars including Jenny who is here with us today as first lady it's my ultimate
mission to end the shame and stigma of the chronic disease of addiction stigma
which is defined as a mark of disgrace is a persistent barrier to effectively
confronting addiction and finding a recovery with addiction stigma puts up
walls instead of building bridges it is socially constructed based in fear and
usually contains in accurate information I met the parents of a teenage boy who
died of an opioid overdose in his truck in his high-school parking lot
they were devastated by their sons needless death however there was no
outpouring of community support like there would be from a teenager who died of cancer or in a car accident shame and
stigma keep people away I believe addiction needs to be embraced like any
other chronic progressively fatal illness or disease like diabetes before
real changes can be made in communities and before the shame and stigma can be
eliminated addiction is not a choice it
is not a character flaw and it does not discriminate now more than ever we must
be driven by data and recognize the science behind the chronic brain disease
of addiction scientists physicians and even the Surgeon General agree that
addiction is a disease when people have the chronic brain disease of addiction
the brain gets hijacked in a biological way manipulating dopamine levels to tell
the person that the highest priority in their life is the disease of addiction and the only choices are drugs and
alcohol it's hard for people to accept the concept that addiction is a disease
I know how hard it is because I didn't accept it myself I thought I could make the right choices
and do the right thing but after relapsing for eight long years I
literally thought I was insane and I now know that no one would choose that life
no one chooses drug overdoses or to lose everything in their lives because of
meth or to die after years of addiction to alcohol like so many of my friends
with compassion we need true understanding and sometimes that understanding comes from having the
humility and courage to unlearn things that we've held as truths for our entire lives
a universal acceptance of the addiction as a disease across our nation will save
lives and provide futures for our next generation of innovators and leaders it
may come as a surprise to you but there's actually a really simple solution to eliminating the stigma of

simple solution is talk if everyone
speaks out about how addiction or recovery has impacted their lives stigma

grassroot movement that costs nothing it doesn't need any legislation and

related to opioid use and addiction by collecting better data to understand the

a critical piece of the data show that 63% of North Dakotans believe that
